--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> As well as =
additive mutations, crossover also results in structure
> being copied thro=
ughout a population and quite possibly faster than
> deletion mutations can=
 remove them. Also the speciation in standard

I don't see how crossover ca=
n contribute to bloat, though.  A child
is, structurally, a clone of the do=
minant parent (i.e., the parent
with highest fitness).  Crossover only occu=
rs in the weights of
connections shared by both parents.

That's the way we=
 implemented it in ANJI, anyway.  Have others done
differently, where the c=
hild contains a union of parent genes?

- Philip
